message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Handbook on Socially Interactive Agents
Paper Abstract: International audience
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.
purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text: Social interaction | allowed_domains: ['en.wikipedia.org']
purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Social interaction"

Links: [{"title":"Social interaction approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_interaction_approach"},{"title":"Social Interaction Anxiety Scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Interaction_Anxiety_Scale"},{"title":"Social relation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_relation"},{"title":"Transformed social interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformed_social_interaction"},{"title":"Social cognition and interaction training - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_cognition_and_interaction_training"},{"title":"Memory and social interactions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_and_social_interactions"},{"title":"Social interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Social_interaction&redirect=no"},{"title":"Social contact - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contact"},{"title":"Social simulation game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_simulation_game"},{"title":"Interaction frequency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_frequency"}]

Based on the web search results for "social interaction," here's what I found:

## General Definition

A social relation is the fundamental unit of analysis within the social sciences, and describes any voluntary or involuntary interpersonal relationship between two or more people within and/or between groups.

## Types of Interaction

Interaction can be either direct or indirect. Interaction is direct when participants exchange roles, and indirect when roles cannot be exchanged. Face-to-face conversations, phone calls, and on-line chats are direct interactions. TV shows, radio programs, videos and books are forms of indirect interaction.

## Role of Symbols

Symbols define social relationships. Without symbols, our social life would be no more sophisticated than that of animals.

## Memory and Social Interaction

In order to engage in successful social interaction, people must be able to remember how they should interact with one another, whom they have interacted with previously, and what occurred during those interactions.

## Interaction Frequency

In sociology, interaction frequency is the total number of social interactions per unit time.

The search results cover various aspects of social interaction from sociological, psychological, and therapeutic perspectives, including research on anxiety related to social interactions, the role of memory, and how social interactions function in different contexts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_metadata.raw_tool_output:
Web search results for query: "Social interaction"

Links: [{"title":"Social interaction approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_interaction_approach"},{"title":"Social Interaction Anxiety Scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Interaction_Anxiety_Scale"},{"title":"Social relation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_relation"},{"title":"Transformed social interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformed_social_interaction"},{"title":"Social cognition and interaction training - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_cognition_and_interaction_training"},{"title":"Memory and social interactions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_and_social_interactions"},{"title":"Social interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Social_interaction&redirect=no"},{"title":"Social contact - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contact"},{"title":"Social simulation game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_simulation_game"},{"title":"Interaction frequency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_frequency"}]

Based on the web search results for "social interaction," here's what I found:

## General Definition

A social relation is the fundamental unit of analysis within the social sciences, and describes any voluntary or involuntary interpersonal relationship between two or more people within and/or between groups.

## Types of Interaction

Interaction can be either direct or indirect. Interaction is direct when participants exchange roles, and indirect when roles cannot be exchanged. Face-to-face conversations, phone calls, and on-line chats are direct interactions. TV shows, radio programs, videos and books are forms of indirect interaction.

## Role of Symbols

Symbols define social relationships. Without symbols, our social life would be no more sophisticated than that of animals.

## Memory and Social Interaction

In order to engage in successful social interaction, people must be able to remember how they should interact with one another, whom they have interacted with previously, and what occurred during those interactions.

## Interaction Frequency

In sociology, interaction frequency is the total number of social interactions per unit time.

The search results cover various aspects of social interaction from sociological, psychological, and therapeutic perspectives, including research on anxiety related to social interactions, the role of memory, and how social interactions function in different contexts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Intelligent agent"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"JACK Intelligent Agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JACK_Intelligent_Agents"},{"title":"Talk:Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Foundation for Intelligent Physical Agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_for_Intelligent_Physical_Agents"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Virtual assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_personal_assistant"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Intelligence agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Intelligence_agent&redirect=no"}]

## Search Results for "Intelligent Agent"

Here's what I found about intelligent agents:

### Definition

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

### Key Characteristics

A basic thermostat or control system is considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria—such as a firm, a state, or a biome.(no content)Intelligent agents operate based on an objective function, which encapsulates their goals, and they are designed to create and execute plans that maximize the expected value of this function upon completion.

### Agentic AI

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments. Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight.

### Applications

Intelligent agents have diverse applications ranging from software agents like virtual assistants that can perform a range of tasks or services for a user based on user input such as commands or questions, to embodied agents that interact with the environment through a physical body within that environment.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

todos.content: Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification**: Survey
- "The Handbook on Socially Interactive Agents" is classified as a **survey** paper, as it's a handbook that reviews existing work in the field.

**Extracted Triples** (2 entities):

1. **Intelligent Agent** (concept)
   - Relation: uses
   - Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent
   - Relevance: The core concept of socially interactive agents builds upon the foundational theory of intelligent agents that perceive their environment and act autonomously.

2. **Social Relation** (concept)
   - Relation: uses
   - Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_relation
   - Relevance: Social interaction between agents requires understanding social relations, the fundamental unit of analysis for interpersonal relationships.

**Validation**: ✅ Passed
- All checks passed successfully
- Paper type: survey
- Total triples: 2
- Entity types: concept (2)

The triples_output.json file has been updated with the complete analysis and passed all validation checks.

Sources:
- [Intelligent agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent)
- [Social relation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_relation)
